name: Grandma's Garlic Shrimp Recipe
description: This sweet garlicky shrimp is a dish my grandma made that is so good I still remember it to this day. Soft, chunky pieces of garlic in a sweet-salty sauce. It's so tasty, and so quick and easy!

video.name: Grandma's Garlic Shrimp Recipe
video.description: Garlic shrimp stir fry is a dish my grandma makes often. Quick and easy meal for a weeknight, use gluten-free oyster sauce to make this a gluten free meal.

recipeIngredient: 1 ½ tsp shrimp paste in oil (see note 1)
1 lb large shrimp (peeled and deveined (see note 3))
Chopped cilantro or green onions for garnish

recipeInstructions.text: Make the sauce by combining the oyster sauce, fish sauce, sugar, water and shrimp paste. Stir to dissolve the sugar.
recipeInstructions.name: Make the sauce by combining the oyster sauce, fish sauce, sugar, water and shrimp paste. Stir to dissolve the sugar.

recipeInstructions.text: Pound garlic until chunky. Remove all but about 1 clove’s worth from the mortar. To the garlic in the mortar, add peppercorns, and cilantro stems and pound into a paste.
recipeInstructions.name: Pound garlic until chunky. Remove all but about 1 clove’s worth from the mortar. To the garlic in the mortar, add peppercorns, and cilantro stems and pound into a paste.

recipeInstructions.text: Dry the shrimp well with a paper towel, and if you’re leaving the tail on be sure to dry the tail extra carefully as water can collect there and cause a lot of splattering in the pan.
recipeInstructions.name: Dry the shrimp well with a paper towel, and if you’re leaving the tail on be sure to dry the tail extra carefully as water can collect there and cause a lot of splattering in the pan.

recipeInstructions.text: In a wok over high heat, add enough oil to coat the bottom. Once the oil is very  hot, lay the shrimp down in one layer; you will need to do this in 2 batches. Let the shrimp sear until at least halfway cooked and slightly browned on the underside. Flip and cook the other side just until done (timing will depend on the size of the shrimp, but it should take no more than a few minutes total). Remove the pan from the heat and take out the shrimp, leaving all the oil behind. Repeat with the other half.
recipeInstructions.name: In a wok over high heat, add enough oil to coat the bottom. Once the oil is very  hot, lay the shrimp down in one layer; you will need to do this in 2 batches. Let the shrimp sear until at least halfway cooked and slightly browned on the underside. Flip and cook the other side just until done (timing will depend on the size of the shrimp, but it should take no more than a few minutes total). Remove the pan from the heat and take out the shrimp, leaving all the oil behind. Repeat with the other half.

recipeInstructions.text: Allow the pan to cool for a minute, then add the chunky garlic and turn the heat back on to medium low. Add more oil if needed, then saute the garlic for about 2 minutes or until softened and the edges start to turn golden. Add the herb paste and saute for 15-20 seconds.
recipeInstructions.name: Allow the pan to cool for a minute, then add the chunky garlic and turn the heat back on to medium low. Add more oil if needed, then saute the garlic for about 2 minutes or until softened and the edges start to turn golden. Add the herb paste and saute for 15-20 seconds.

recipeInstructions.text: Turn the heat up to medium and add the cooked shrimp including all the collected juices. Add the sauce mixture, then toss for about 30 seconds to mix and reduce the sauce slightly.
recipeInstructions.name: Turn the heat up to medium and add the cooked shrimp including all the collected juices. Add the sauce mixture, then toss for about 30 seconds to mix and reduce the sauce slightly.

recipeInstructions.text: Plate and garnish with chopped cilantro and/or green onions and/or fried garlic, if desired. Serve with jasmine rice.

review.reviewBody: Oh, I forgot. A must is to do the fried crisp garlic to sprinkle on top. Elevates the dish

I can confirm that this is similar to stir fired garlic and (white) pepper shrimp, the sauce is heavenly delicious, when you cook do at least 2 times more to soak your rise.
I also did the Gai (chicken) variant, using thighs (fry them hard to get the browning) and the shrimp paste, and it comes out as good.
Great recipe. I added two bird eye chilis to the herb paste and some angel hair pasta in the last minute of cooking. It’s such a pungent flavor and such a fast prep. Highly recommend.
Fabulous!  Next will make with more sauce.  Such a hit!

I was nervous because I couldn't find oyster sauce or shrimp paste in time but WOW. I'm relatively new to cooking, and this recipe is a game-changer. My wife loved it too. Frying up the shrimp got pretty dramatic because I put a lid on it and then the condensation started falling back into the oil and going crazy, but I persevered. DELICIOUS. Excited to try it again but with shrimp paste and oyster sauce!

I'm in shock - I made this and it tasted better than restaurant quality, which is amazing!  This recipe is simple with clear and precise instructions with pictures of the paste and video to follow along.  Thank you so much for sharing this wonderful recipe.  This is a keeper!

So simple and so delicious!  Made it tonight and my husband couldn't stop talking about how good it was.  With a little jasmine rice and a separate cabbage shitake stir fry dish on the side. Thank you!
